Was I the only person to be saddened by this announcement?  Maybe I'm
just =
being sentimental here but the Graphical TestRunner's green bar/red
bar was=
 one of the earliest delights of Junit.

Besides, as a casual user of Java =
I have yet to find the energy to learn
an IDE.  When I do have to code Java=
 I generally use my normal text
editor and the graphical test runner, which=
 I find is quicker and easier
to use than the text version.

I know Kent ha=
s an evangelising streak - automated unit testing,
xp/agile, etc - which he=
 has used well in the service of the software
community but I think insisti=
ng on the use of an IDE is a crusade too
far.

Cheers, APC

-----Original M=
essage-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On B=
ehalf Of
Kent Beck
Sent: 18 August 2005 17:07
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sub=
ject: RE: [junit] Some questions about JUnit 4

Elliotte,

Thank you for th=
e offer, but we are fairly certain that we do not want
to include the graph=
ical runners in JUnit 4. I can see that they might
be useful in a teaching =
situation, but we are assuming that an IDE will
always be available or that=
 the textual interface will suffice.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Riv=
ers Institute
